STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
March 14, 2024
Sara Miller
Child & Family Services of The Upper Peninsula
706 Chippewa Sq,
Marquette, MI, 49855-4834
RE: License#: CB520201043
Dear Ms. Miller:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed
on February 6, 2024. A corrective action plan is required. The corrective action plan is
due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the
corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact Samantha Way, Area Manager, at 517-243-9743.
Sincerely,
Douglas Turrill, Licensing Consultant
enclosure
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
RENEWAL INSPECTION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
License #: CB520201043
Licensee Group Organization: Child & Family Service of U P
Licensee Designee: Sara Lynn Miller
Chief Administrator: Sara Lynn Miller
Name of Agency: Child & Family Services of the Upper
Peninsula
Agency Address: 706 Chippewa Sq
Marquette, MI 49855-4834
Agency Telephone #: 9062284025
Original Issuance Date: 09/01/1990
Service Types: Place children for adoption, Certify foster
homes for license, Supervise Independent
Living, Place children in foster home,
Evaluate Applicants for adoption

II. METHODS OF INSPECTION

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except for
the following:
FOM 722-08D Treatment Plans
Once completed and approved, the caseworker must
obtain signatures from the following individuals, as
applicable:
• Caseworker.
• Supervisor.
• Second line supervisor, when siblings in care are
placed apart.
•Parents who are a member of a participating
household.
• Youth ages 14 and older.
•Foster parents, relative caregivers, and unrelated
court ordered caregivers.
The caseworker must obtain signatures from all
applicable individuals and upload the signature
pages into the electronic case record within 30 days
of the report date.
Seven files and nineteen service plans were reviewed. Four of seven files had
treatment plans that were signed more than thirty days from the date of the service
plan. Therefore, the signature pages were not uploaded into the electronic case
record within 30 days of the report date.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED:
4 /3/2023 INTERIM, CAP approved 5/5/2023

FOM 722-06B Family Team Meetings
Case Plan Development/ Reassessment Initial Case
Plan (ISP) - within 30 calendar days before the case
plan due date. Note: This FTM may be combined with
the CPS Case Opening (ISP) FTM. Updated Case Plan
(USP) - within 30 calendar days before the case plan
due date. Permanent Ward Service Plan (PWSP) -
within 30 calendar days before the case plan due date.
The DHS-1105, Family Team Meeting Report, is used
to capture family demographics, FTM logistical
information, needs, strengths, action steps, safety
concerns and the safety plan, and any
recommendations made for the family during the
FTM. The DHS-1105, Family Team Meeting Report,
must be completed for every FTM.
Seven files were reviewed. Two of seven files documented that the case
reassessment FTM was held more than thirty days from the due date of the service
plan.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED:
4/3/2023 INTERIM, CAP approved 5/5/2023.
FOM 801-03 Medical Passport
All medical information within the medical passport
must be current and updated at least quarterly to
reflect the child's current and complete health
information.
Seven files were reviewed. Three of seven files did not document updated medical
passports.

FOM 722-06H Case Contacts
Quality visits between the case manager and child
have been found to produce positive outcomes for
children in care. A quality visit is defined as one in
which the case manager:
• Can meet with each child individually, without the
presence of other individuals, to give the child an
opportunity to ask questions as well as discuss the
current placement.
• Views the child's bedroom and sleeping
arrangements.
• Verifies safe sleep environments and practices for
infants under 12 months.
• Assesses each child’s educational, medical, dental,
mental health, and other needs and takes
appropriate action or offers services in response to
the identified needs of each child.
• Shows interest in the child to build and establish
rapport.
• Shares and explains the case plan, including the
plan for parenting time, visits with siblings and other
relatives, and the child's permanency plan, in a
developmentally appropriate way while allowing the
child to ask questions and express viewpoints.
Seven files were reviewed. One of seven contained an in-home case contact that
did not document that the worker met with the child privately and did not assess
safety of the home.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following area:
• R 400.12328 (4) Foster Home Record. If any “hard copy” CHRI related
documents are obtained or generated by the agency the documents
should be maintained for a period of 7 years after case closure.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
• Consultation was not requested or provided at this time.

VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There was 1 substantiated incident of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period. The agency initiated special evaluation #2023C0000150, on December 8,
2022, and concluded the investigation on October 4, 2023. The investigation
established a violation of R 400,9201-1-b, Foster Home applicant and licensee
qualiifications. The foster parent had hit a child multiple times and had pulled the child
by his hair for a distance. The agency recommended revocation of the licese.
There was 1 incident of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period. The agency initiated special evaluation #2023C0000150 on December 8,
2022 and concluded the investigation on October 4, 2023. The investigation
established a violation of R 400,9201-1-b, Foster Home applicant and licensee
qualifications. The foster parent had hit a child multiple times and had pulled the child
by his hair for a distance. The agency recommended revocation of the license.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 1 acceptable corrective action plan (CAP) during this
licensing period. The CAP submitted on April 25, 2023, was in response to those
violations established during the interim inspection completed on April 3, 2023.
The violations established during the interim inspection are as follows:
1. FOM 722-08D Treatment Plans.
2. FOM 722-06B Family Team Meetings
3. R 400. 12311 Foster parent/agency agreement
4. R 400.12326 Borrowed Home
The current renewal inspection established repeat violations of FOM 722-08D and
FOM 722-06B. The agency CAP was successful in preventing repeat violations of
R 400.12311 and R 400.12326. Additional corrective planning will be completed to
address the repeated violations.
There were no special investigations of the agency during this licensing period.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrators Assessment was reviewed. The assessment addressed
rule violations and the agency actions to prevent repeat or additional violations.
The assessment addressed barriers to compliance including the difficulty of cases
referred to the agency and finding appropriate and effective placements for
children. Additional barriers included the large geographical area the agency
services. Workloads, in addition to the large area the agency covers, places
additional burdens on service workers. The frequent difficulties with working within
the MISACWIS and CWLM systems were also noted as a barrier.
Financial Overview
The agency annual budget and a certified public accountant audit of the agency
was reviewed. No concerns were noted, and the agency is fiscally viable.

Staff Interviews
Staff interviewed reported enjoying working for the agency and they have a strong
supportive team. Staff also reported they have a supportive, knowledgeable
supervisor.
Description of Agency Walk Through
The agency is located in a modern building in Marquette. There is adequate office
space, and it is well equipped.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
The CPA Analyst established two safety alerts during her visits to the homes. They
are as follows:
Safety Alert #1. The safety alert was generated on November 30, 2023, as bows and
arrows were found to not be secured and stored properly. The agency was notified on
the same date. Resolution occurred on December 4, 2023, and photos were provided
which established the bows were cable locked and arrows stored in a gun cabinet.
Safety Alert #2. The safety alert was generated on January 3, 2024, and sent to the
agency on January 5, 2024. A basement bedroom ceiling was not sealed or painted.
A variance was submitted on January 11, 2024. The foster home then requested that
their license be closed.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency will be issued a renewal of their regular license.
March 1, 2024
_____________________________________
Douglas Turrill Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
March, 14, 2024___________________________
Samantha Way Date
Area Manager
